results.abstract: Flentrop organ at Performing Arts Center of Purchase College is 29 feet high and 19 feet long; Assoc Prof Robert Fertitta will play organ in three works with Westchester Philharmonic on Nov 9 and Nov 10; photos (M)

headline.main: A Concert Where the Organ Reigns

results.snippet: THE Flentrop organ, a 29-foot-high, 19-foot-long portable mammoth, commands its own room at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College here, where it awaits rare excursions onto the concert stage. There it looms majestically over the audience,...
results.lead_paragraph: THE Flentrop organ, a 29-foot-high, 19-foot-long portable mammoth, commands its own room at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College here, where it awaits rare excursions onto the concert stage. There it looms majestically over the audience, its 4,200 pipes encased in mahogany. The player seated at the built-in console of the instrument appears an incidental part of the machinery -- almost an afterthought in the visceral power of the music. Robert Fertitta, who will play the Flentrop in three works with the Westchester Philharmonic here next Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M., compares himself to an astronaut navigating a space shuttle through the cosmos. For Mr. Fertitta, the cosmos is the point, not the lowly astronaut; the music, not the musician.

results.abstract: Russian Mars space probe that failed to break out of Earth orbit re-enters Earth's atmosphere above southern Pacific Ocean west of South America and apparently crashes into sea; failure, which apparently occurred when booster rocket failed to ignite, deals devastating blow to Russia's shrunken and badly underfinanced space program (M)

headline.main: Russia's Mars Craft Fails and Crashes in Southern Pacific

results.snippet: The remnants of an unmanned Russian space probe that failed to break out of Earth's orbit re-entered the atmosphere above the southern Pacific Ocean west of South America tonight and apparently crashed into the sea, American officials said.    The...
results.lead_paragraph: The remnants of an unmanned Russian space probe that failed to break out of Earth's orbit re-entered the atmosphere above the southern Pacific Ocean west of South America tonight and apparently crashed into the sea, American officials said. The failure, which apparently occurred when a booster rocket did not ignite, dealt a devastating blow to Russia's shrunken and badly underfinanced space program.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Columbia will be launched from Cape Canaveral on November 19 with five-member crew, including 61-year-old Story Musgrave--space agency's oldest astronaut (M)Ãˆ

headline.main: Shuttle Crew With Oldest Astronaut Is Set to Fly

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia was scheduled to be launched on Tuesday with a five-member crew that includes the space agency's oldest astronaut, officials said today.    Workers on the launching pad reported no major technical problems with the $2...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia was scheduled to be launched on Tuesday with a five-member crew that includes the space agency's oldest astronaut, officials said today. Workers on the launching pad reported no major technical problems with the $2 billion spaceship, which is supposed to blast off at 2:53 P.M.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Columbia blasts into orbit, first launching since National Aeronautic and Space Administration began gradual shift of shuttle work to United Space Alliance; crew of five includes Dr Story Musgrave, 61, oldest astronaut ever; will deploy and retrieve two scientific satellites and test construction and maintenance techniques for future orbital space station during 16-day mission; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Blasts Off on Mission With 2 Scientific Satellites

results.snippet: The nation's oldest space shuttle, the 15-year-old Columbia, blasted into orbit today carrying the oldest astronaut ever to fly in space, 61-year-old Dr. Story Musgrave. Neither showed any effects of age.    The winged spaceplane and its five-member...
results.lead_paragraph: The nation's oldest space shuttle, the 15-year-old Columbia, blasted into orbit today carrying the oldest astronaut ever to fly in space, 61-year-old Dr. Story Musgrave. Neither showed any effects of age. The winged spaceplane and its five-member crew were off on a planned 16-day mission to deploy and then retrieve two scientific satellites and conduct two space walks for testing techniques to be used in constructing and maintaining a future orbital space station. The first satellite, an ultraviolet telescope, was released eight hours after takeoff.

results.abstract: NASA scientists correct problems with alignment of ultraviolet telescope orbiting behind space shuttle Columbia, and instrument begins making scientific observations (S)

headline.main: Repairs Made To Telescope Near Shuttle

results.snippet: Researchers corrected problems with the alignment of the ultraviolet telescope orbiting behind the space shuttle Columbia today, and the instrument began scientific observations.    ''We're getting things rolling,'' said Ronald Polidan, the...
results.lead_paragraph: Researchers corrected problems with the alignment of the ultraviolet telescope orbiting behind the space shuttle Columbia today, and the instrument began scientific observations. ''We're getting things rolling,'' said Ronald Polidan, the astrophysicist with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration who is managing the project. ''We have lots of happy faces, and our status board is full of very excited exclamation points.''

results.abstract: NASA postpones space walk for two astronauts because of stuck hatch on space shuttle Columbia (M)

headline.main: Hatch Won't Open, and Space Walk Is Put Off

results.snippet: Two astronauts about to go out on a space walk today encountered a stuck hatch, and the space agency postponed the excursion.    After pushing and jiggling the handle for more than two hours, two of the space shuttle Columbia's astronauts, Dr. Tamara...
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts about to go out on a space walk today encountered a stuck hatch, and the space agency postponed the excursion. After pushing and jiggling the handle for more than two hours, two of the space shuttle Columbia's astronauts, Dr. Tamara E. Jernigan and Dr. Thomas D. Jones, were finally told to give up.

results.abstract: New video releases include two Cabbage Patch Kid videos made by Xavier Roberts, who originated Cabbage Patch dolls; photo (M)
results.snippet: New videos are coming from all angles and places. For example, once in rural Georgia a fabric sculptor named Xavier Roberts made a line of cloth figures so lovably ugly he got people to ''adopt'' them at $40 each. In the current movie ''Jingle All...
results.lead_paragraph: New videos are coming from all angles and places. For example, once in rural Georgia a fabric sculptor named Xavier Roberts made a line of cloth figures so lovably ugly he got people to ''adopt'' them at $40 each. In the current movie ''Jingle All the Way,'' frantic parents race to procure the last Turbo Man action toy before Christmas. In 1983 the battle was fought for real over Mr. Roberts's Cabbage Patch Kids. Now there are the Cabbage Patch Kid videos, a pair of 30-minute stop-action animation stories. On tape as in fabric, Mr. Roberts had his own notions about what he wanted; others, including Hollywood, had theirs. ''They kept saying they wanted villains,'' Mr. Roberts said. ''Well, I didn't want villains or heroes, but basically just things children deal with growing up.''

results.abstract: NASA engineers pore over documents and photographs to try to find way to open stuck hatch on space shuttle Columbia and salvage plans for space walk considered crucial practice for station construction; photo (M)

headline.main: NASA Engineers Try to Salvage Space Walk

results.snippet: NASA engineers pored over documents and photographs today to try to find a way to open a stuck hatch on the space shuttle Columbia and salvage plans for a space walk considered crucial practice for station construction.    NASA engineers saw nothing...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA engineers pored over documents and photographs today to try to find a way to open a stuck hatch on the space shuttle Columbia and salvage plans for a space walk considered crucial practice for station construction. NASA engineers saw nothing obstructing the six latches on the hatch, leading them to suspect that the hatch could be slightly out of alignment, a problem the astronauts might be able to get around with some well-placed shoves.
